headline: DeWine expected to unveil Intel plans during 'historic economic development announcement'
author: Eleanor Kennedy
sentences: "Whoever it is thinking about putting this plant in is going to have to recruit nationally and globally to get the workforce – that level of specialization isn’t here because this is a new industry (for the region)," said Bill LaFayette, owner of Columbus consulting firm Regionomics LLC.

Intel's plan for such a facility is in keeping with CEO Pat Gelsinger's goal to establish the company's role as a cornerstone for any national semiconductor strategy, as reported by the Portland Business Journal, a Columbus Business First sister publication.

The new chip factories, known in the industry as fabs, were expected to create over 3,000 permanent high-tech, high-wage jobs; over 3,000 construction jobs; and approximately 15,000 local long-term jobs, according to Intel, the PBJ reported.

As first reported by our corporate siblings at Cleveland.com, Columbus Business First has confirmed the California-based company is the microchip manufacturer behind plans for such a facility in the Columbus suburb.

In August, Gelsinger told the Washington Post the company was soliciting proposals for a project that would include six to eight fabs, representing $100 billion of investment, to be built over the next decade.
Although the release from the governor's office is light on details, that's the day an announcement has been expected regarding Intel Corp.'s plan for a semiconductor plant in New Albany.
The deal is said to be the largest economic development deal in state history, and such a plant could have a massive impact on the region, one economist told Columbus Business First.
"Essentially, we want to build a little city," Gelsinger said of the project, which would create 10,000 direct jobs and tenfold that indirectly.
Jon Husted and state economic development officials will make a "historic economic development announcement" Friday afternoon.
Intel is expected to employ thousands at the New Albany factory, set to occupy land being annexed from Jersey Township.
Friday's announcement will be held at the Midland Theatre in Newark, and will be live-streamed via the Ohio Channel.
Last year the company announced plans to invest $20 billion in two new semiconductor factories in Arizona.
"Because it’s new and different, it’s going to transform the economy."
